name: Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley National Monument
description: In 1955, 14-year-old Emmett Till traveled to Money, Mississippi, to visit relatives. He was kidnapped, tortured, and murdered after reportedly whistling at a white woman. His mother, Mamie Till-Mobley, insisted on an open-casket funeral near their hometown of Chicago. Her brave decision let the world see the racist violence inflicted upon her son and set the Civil Rights Movement into motion.
shortDescription: In 1955, 14-year-old Emmett Till traveled to Money, Mississippi, to visit relatives. He was kidnapped, tortured, and murdered after reportedly whistling at a white woman. His mother, Mamie Till-Mobley...

climate.weatherDescription: The Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley National Monument has sites in Chicago, IL and Sumner and Glendora, MS. Check local weather conditions in each unit before you visit.

images.title: Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley
images.altText: Two African Americans sitting in a room and smiling toward the camera.
images.caption: Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley, ca. 1954.
images.credit: NAACP Records, Prints and Photographs Division, Library of Congress

images.title: Roberts Temple Church of God in Christ
images.altText: A multi-story tan brick church along a road. A tree stands in front.
images.caption: Roberts Temple Church of God in Christ in Chicago.
images.credit: Battiest Photography / National Trust for Historic Preservation

images.title: Roberts Temple Church of God in Christ Interior
images.altText: Rows of green seats in a large white room pointed toward a pulpit and a cross on a wall.
images.caption: Present-day photo of the Inside of Roberts Temple Church of God in Christ.
images.credit: Battiest Photography / National Trust for Historic Preservation

images.title: Reverend Wheeler Parker Jr.
images.altText: An elderly African American man looks at a plaque on the church exterior.
images.caption: Reverend Wheeler Parker Jr., cousin and last living witness of Emmett Tillâ€™s kidnapping, viewing Chicago Landmark plaque on Roberts Temple Church of God in Christ.
images.credit: Battiest Photography / National Trust for Historic Preservation

images.title: Emmett Till Interpretive Center
images.altText: A one story store-like front along a street containing two doors and several windows.
images.caption: The Emmett Till Interpretive Center in Sumner, MS, an official nonprofit partner of Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley National Monument.

images.title: Emmett Till Interpretive Center Interior
images.altText: Six chairs sit in a circle in a room that is lined with informational panels.
images.caption: Interior of the Emmett Till Interpretive Center.

images.title: Emmett Till Interpretive Center 2
images.altText: A table sits besides shelves featuring magazines and books in a white room.
images.caption: Interior of the Emmett Till Interpretive Center.

images.title: Tallahatchie County Courthouse Courtroom
images.altText: Rows of seats face a bench in an empty courtroom.
images.caption: Present-day interior view of the Tallahatchie County Courthouse courtroom where the trial of the men accused of lynching Emmett Till took place took place.

images.title: Tallahatchie County Courthouse
images.altText: Side view of a two-story brick courthouse with a clock tower. A statue stands in front.
images.caption: The Tallahatchie County Courthouse in Sumner, MS.

images.title: Graball Landing
images.altText: View of a muddy river from between two trees.
images.caption: Graball Landing in Glendora, MS.
